🎯 Key Takeaways for quick navigation:

00:00 📂 Obsidian: A Timeless Note-Taking Solution
- Obsidian is a folder-based note-taking app that uses text files.
- Notes in Obsidian are stored as text files, making them highly portable and independent of proprietary web services.
- Unlike other note-taking apps, Obsidian's notes are universally accessible across various platforms and text editors, ensuring long-term usability and freedom from DRM restrictions.

The problem is, every intro like this glosses over the central limitation of Obsidian: the vault. Everything centers on the 'vault'--how your files are organized, where they are, etc. And the vault creates some barriers to sharing between computers (yes, I know--'plugins'). Like many people, I want to be able to edit and share my files between multiple machines without plugins, databases, etc. You could easily make Vault accomodate this out of the box. Why not do it?

I'm over Obsidian now. I've used it since it started, and I still have an early bird discount! The App is really a platform, and it can just take over everything, but it needs managing, and it ended up being stressful and overwhelming. The security thing is a red herring, as I also found out, just because it's on local storage doesn't mean it is safe!! I can say lots more so ask any questions you want

Obsidian is a constant "almost" for me. The lack of a truly functional WYSIWYG ability to write is highly offputting to me, constantly seeing my font jump around and move, it just distracts me in a way that I can't fully explain. As if the cursor was jumping back and forth (because it kinda is.)

The second this is that I'm a highly visual note taker. I use colored and stylized font a lot to make specific information stand out for rapid accessibility. Obsidian barely supports color, and you generally have to use extensions which are mauling your note with CSS code behind the scenes (and any time you edit the colored text) - plus relying on such a method removes any confidence in being able to easily migrate to another system. I get why people use markdown, I just come from a different era and use a different style.

I have tried several times over the years to migrate, but it just never works out. The compromises I need to make on my own style just aren't worth it... which is a huge shame because I love Obsidian, and the ethos of the makers and community, and the ecosystem, and the style, and everything else. I'm happy to pay even... but I just can't make it work the way I need. It's like the best meal you ever ate, with a giant dead rat right in the middle of the dish -- and you didn't see it until after the first few bites...
The best note taking app. I've used Evernote forever but moved to obsidian few years ago and never looked back. Still no android widget but that's ok.

Not a single word about compatible accessibility features for Obsidian. This is why I don’t even bother to test it out. If there’s no screen reader support, it’s an automatic “no” from me. It takes a couple of seconds to say whether a tool is accessible or not in a general review, but no one does it.

Great review Francesco! I've been using Obsidian for a while now. It is possible to sync using git. But that's more for users who have a bit more technical experience. There are instructions that can be found on youtube and Obsidian forums if someone wants to try. But backup your data first! To back up, copy the vault somewhere else (cloud drive, external drive or simply another folder).

Once you have git set up, it can allow you to version your files so you can revert back to an earlier version or recover a file you might have deleted. Again all of this is much easier if you already know how to use git. Their sync product is great and not horribly expensive, so if you have the money and don't like tinkering I highly suggest using Obsidian Sync instead.
